item.title: Umamusume: Pretty Derby - Best Way to Get Money (Monies)
item.description:
You can't have a gacha game without having some form of currency for upgrades, and in Umamusume: Pretty Derby, Money (or Monies, in-game) is what you'll need to give your trainees the edge they need to win more races. You'll likely get Monies simply by playing, but if you want to maximize your earnings, you'll need to play the right races.

If you're having trouble getting your trainees' stats in Umamusume up, then some upgrades are likely warranted. These can get pretty expensive, however, and for that, you'll need to keep a nice stock of Monies handy.

Best Way to Get Money in Umamusume

Playing through a trainee's career or story mode will net you a nice amount of Monies in total, but in order to really start stacking cash as soon as possible, you'll want to complete your Daily Races . You can find the Daily Race option in the Race tab at the bottom of the main menu screen. It's right between the Home and Scout buttons . You can use any of your owned characters to participate in these races.

As their name implies, Daily Races are limited, with players only being able to participate in six races per day . Each race consumes a ticket, and when you're all out of tickets, you won't be able to race anymore until you get more tickets the following day.

Daily Races are divided by difficulty and race length , with harder races being more rewarding. You'll start with just Easy mode available, but placing first in each race difficulty, you'll unlock the next difficulty level.

Ideally, you should be doing Hard races to get the most money per racing ticket. However, if you can't comfortably place in the top three in every Hard race you compete in, you're better off playing Normal races.

You'll get a Participation reward in Umamusume Daily Races regardless of whether you win or lose. Easy rewards 1000 Monies, Normal gives 2000, and Hard gives 3000. You get bonus Monies depending on how well your trainee places at the end of the race.

Umamusume Career Mode

A complete Career mode playthrough should reward players with about 10,000 Monies if they manage to win every race, and this does not include any potential Missions that might reward them with Monies, SP, or even Carats. If you're playing Umamusume and you want to get Monies fast, you should at least play one Career run and all of your Daily Missions every day.

Playing Career mode is also great for improving your Trainees for Daily and Team Races. If you're having trouble beating Hard Daily Races, then spend some time training one of your runners in Career mode.

item.title: All Pokemon TCG Pocket Icons (& How to Get Them)
item.description:
The main aim of Pokemon TCG Pocket is to collect new cards to use in battles, but there are also plenty of cosmetic items that players can use to decorate their profile pages. One of the most important customizable elements is the player's icon, as it appears on both friends lists and battle results screens.

There are 43 Pokemon TCG Pocket icons in total, although nine of these are no longer available, having been tied to time-limited events. Players will start with six icons unlocked by default, with the other 34 unlocked through collection events and secret missions. The following guide will explain exactly how to get them.

All Pokemon TCG Pocket Icons / Profile Pictures

item.title: Super Smash Bros: 7 Most Controversial Characters In The Series, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Pichu is controversial due to damaging itself in battles, raising questions about his place in the roster.
  • Meta Knight was divisive due to his all-around strength in combat, making him a challenging opponent in Brawl.
  • Cloud's overwhelming strength in the game led to heated discussions and nerfs, causing controversy among fans.

With a stacked roster of over 90 playable fighters to choose from, it's fair to say there is certainly no shortage of iconic characters to pick from when loading into a game of Super Smash Bros. Ultimate . However, while the majority of these characters are beloved and have gone on to become fan favorites, there have definitely also been a select few who could be considered a little more divisive, and there are a few reasons why this could end up being the case.

On the one hand, while it's established that virtually anyone can join in on Smash , some third-party characters can still feel a little out of place, taking up a slot which maybe could have been reserved for someone more fitting. Of course, there's also the chance that a character can end up being a little too strong for their own good in the game itself, which can also make them pretty polarizing in the eyes of fans. With that in mind, these are among the most divisive characters that have shown up in the immensely popular Super Smash Bros. series.

7 Pichu

As A Joke Character, Pichu Isn't As Beloved As Most Other Fighters

  • First Introduced : Super Smash Bros. Melee

Joke characters are nothing new in the world of fighting games, though considering they still take up a character slot, they are often seen as somewhat controversial among many fans, and this also relates to Pichu. The main issue with Pichu is that, despite being an Electric-type Pokemon, any of its attacks that involve electricity will cause damage to itself.

As a result, people simply brushed the character to the side, but once it became popular within Smash tournaments, many began to wonder whether Pichu should even be in the series at all, considering he's always playing at a disadvantage. At the same time, there aren't many people out there who are going to be opposed to more Pokemon being added to a Smash game, so Pichu is a fighter who every fan has their personal opinion on.

6 Meta Knight

Meta Knight's Mobility And Strength Made Him A Terrifying Foe To Take On In Brawl

  • First Introduced : Super Smash Bros. Brawl

Super Smash Bros Brawl was the game that opened up the floodgates in terms of what characters could be introduced to the series. However, while Snake and Sonic were the primary characters that took many fans by surprise, it would end up being Meta Knight who was the most talked about among most pro players at the time. Usually, Smash characters will excel in one or two areas in combat, but Meta Knight was simply good all around.

His wings enabled him to effortlessly avoid incoming attacks while also closing the gap on his opponents in barely any time at all. This isn't even mentioning his neutral attacks, which would basically act as an impenetrable defense, making it extremely difficult to even get close, let alone damage him. While he was never considered outright broken, Meta Knight in Brawl was still an especially tricky opponent who some came to love, and others would disdain.

5 Cloud

It Seems Like Sakurai Got A Little Carried Away When Adjusting Cloud's Power Level

  • First Introduced : Super Smash Bros. Wii U & 3DS

The reveal that Cloud would be added to Super Smash Bros. for Wii U and 3DS still stands as one of the most shocking reveals in the history of the franchise. Still, while fans were overjoyed to see the classic JRPG protagonist make his way into the roster, it quickly became clear he would be needing some much-needed nerfs as soon as possible.

Cloud's combo attacks with his Buster Sword would be able to shoot people off the screen in mere seconds, even if they were still on a low percentage. At the time of his release, there were some discussions about how many of the other characters were already extremely powerful to begin with, but there were others who picked on Cloud specifically for his overwhelming strength. Ultimately, the controversy surrounding Cloud would disappear as soon as Bayonetta was announced not long after, and while he's in a much better spot these days, long-time fans will never be able to forget the amount of carnage this iconic protagonist caused when he was released.

4 Kazuya

Tekken's Representative Has Amassed An Army Of Both Fans And Haters

  • First Introduced : Super Smash Bros. Ultimate

Considering he is essentially the face of one of the most popular fighting game franchises of all time, nobody was surprised when Kazuya Mishima was announced as a DLC character for Smash Ultimate . As he had done with all the previous DLC fighters, Sakurai made sure that Kazuya played as similarly to his Tekken iteration as possible, for better or worse.

On the one hand, it's a ton of fun being able to throw out Kazuya's classic auto combos to launch someone off the stage, but experienced players were also able to notice a few quirks in Kazuya's kits that made him especially annoying to fight. For example, there's a real weightiness to Kazuya's movement, which can make it feel like he's playing an entirely different game to everyone else. His Devil Form also felt just a tad too strong for its own good, though some argued this was intentional, considering how powerful this form of Kazuya is designed to be in the Tekken lore.

3 Fox

Fox, Even Today, Continues To Dominate The Melee Roster

  • First Introduced : Super Smash Bros. 64

In Super Smash Bros Melee , there are plenty of fun characters to choose from, but those who are eager to win will almost always pick Fox. This character's speed and agility far exceed anyone else in the game, and considering how fast the moment-to-moment gameplay of Melee is, it can often feel impossible for anyone else in the roster to even keep up with him.

Not only that, Fox also has a lightning-fast side dash which can be used to both avoid and damage enemies, and even comes with a great recovery alongside some lethal poke attacks. Fox has been toned down greatly since Melee's release, but even today, he is still by far the most popular character in Melee tournaments, so much so that some people even argue that he should be banned entirely, while others enjoy watching him in action because of his flashy fighting style.

2 Steve

The Quirky Mine Dweller Showed Up To A Mixed Reception From Fans

  • First Introduced : Super Smash Bros. Ultimate

The majority of character reveals for Super Smash Bros. Ultimate ended up going over extremely well with the fans, but the one outlier to this was Steve. Considering Minecraft is one of the most popular games of all time, there was every reason for Steve to show up in some form or another, but while he definitely would have been a good fit being a simple Assist Trophy, the fact that he was made a fully playable character was met with mixed reception.

On the one hand, Minecraft fans, who had been desperately waiting for him to be added to the roster for many years, were finally able to jump into battle with the iconic character, but others felt his design and strange fighting style were just too unorthodox to work in a Smash game. He would only become more polarizing after he was released, with his bizarre building abilities being a lot of fun to use, but an absolute nightmare to fight against.

1 Bayonetta

Bayonetta Turned Out To Be Far Stronger Than Anyone Could Have Anticipated

  • First Introduced : Super Smash Bros. Wii U & 3DS

Super Smash Bros. Ultimate wasn't the first game where Bayonetta caught controversy after appearing on a Nintendo system. When Bayonetta 2 was revealed to be an exclusive for the Wii U, conversations began to rise about whether the hack-and-slash seductress was family-friendly enough to even be on a Nintendo console, though it didn't take long before fans warmed up to the idea, with it soon seeming inevitable that she would eventually make her way to Smash .

However, while it was clear that the Umbra Witch was going to be a formidable foe, nobody could have expected just how insanely powerful she would be when she launched. Her giant demon attacks and Witch Time ability made her virtually untouchable when used in the right hands, to the point where many pros agreed she was objectively the best character in the game for the Wii U version. This even spawned the now iconic clip of the 2018 Evo finals, where the finalists both decided to pick Bayonetta, only for them to be booed by the audience for the entire match. Thankfully, Bayonetta has been nerfed a lot since then and now feels much more fun to play in Smash Ultimate , but to say she was divisive when she was released would be putting it lightly.

item.title: Marvel Rivals Players Celebrate Nerf to Controversial Character
item.description:
Marvel Rivals players are happy with the Wolverine nerfs recently announced by NetEase. The iconic mutant is one of the Marvel Rivals Duelists that players can choose from, and recently attracted attention for receiving adjustments focused on reducing the power of his kit.

The upcoming Marvel Rivals patch will go live on July 17 and will bring nerfs to decrease Wolverine's survivability. With that, the base damage of Berserk Claw Strike and the percentage damage per attack that his ability causes at maximum Rage will be reduced. The devs have increased the cooldown time of Regenerative Healing Factor and increased the cooldown reduction that players get when they score an assist. Additionally, Wolverine's team-up with Jean Grey will be nerfed, giving him less life steal. After revealing these adjustments, the Marvel Rivals community quickly expressed their opinions.

Marvel Rivals players are celebrating the nerfs Wolverine will receive in the July 17 update. On the Marvel Rivals subreddit, user DemiFiendRSA posted the patch notes for the Logan-focused balance. Redditors responded with 1,400 upvotes and over 400 comments, many happy that NetEase has finally addressed the effectiveness of Wolverine's team-up with Phoenix. Others said the patch is in the right direction to adjust the mutant's power, which most comments consider to be broken in Season 3. Another player praised the developers' quick action, saying that Wolverine would be a bigger problem if he weren't quickly nerfed.

Marvel Rivals Announces Nerfs for Wolverine, Players React to the Announcement

While the consensus among players is happiness at finally seeing one of the biggest headaches of the moment in Marvel Rivals being nerfed, other Redditors still feel that the adjustment is not enough. Several players consider that the life steal reduction is still too low, and some even call for its complete removal. Others said they will continue to ban the Marvel Rivals Duelist regardless of the nerfs. Part of the comments section criticized the balancing of characters made around their team-ups, which can be removed at any time.

That is not the first time Marvel Rivals has made a character too strong by giving them a new team-up. With the debut of The Fantastic Four, the Human Torch got a team-up with Storm that quickly drew attention for being very powerful. However, Marvel Rivals removed this team-up at the start of Season 3. As for Wolverine, players hope that these adjustments will make the character less oppressive, making matches less defined by whether he's banned or picked.

item.title: Miyabi Team Composition Guide In Zenless Zone Zero
item.description:
For Miyabi to do her job in Zenless Zone Zero , players must pair her with a Support or someone from her own faction. Considering there aren't many Section 6 characters, Proxies may need to use non-Section 6 characters to make their best Miyabi team comp in ZZZ .

Updated on July 16, 2025, by Nahda Nabiilah : Miyabi team comp continues to grow as the roster of Anomaly Agents expands. Because of that, this article has been updated to offer more options for Miyabi's teams in ZZZ .

The teams in this article are listed in no particular order.

1 Miyabi + Yanagi + Yuzuha

Miyabi's DPS mainly comes from her Basic Attack: Shimotsuki , which can deal a massive amount of DMG if she launches it with 6 stacks of Fallen Frost . Miyabi gains Fallen Frost by:

  • Using EX Special Attack (2 stacks)
  • Casting Ultimate (3 stacks)
  • Triggering Frostburn - Break Anomaly (1 stack)
  • Any squad member triggers Disorder (2 stacks)

So, as you buildup Frostburn through Miyabiâ€™s Ice attacks, keep tapping her EX Special Attacks to build two points of Fallen Frost stacks. Once she's out of Energy, use Basic Attack until Miyabi triggers an Anomaly . When Miyabi has six Fallen Frost stacks, hold her Basic Attack to use all six stacks and deal massive damage.

You can also adjust how long you hold the Basic Attack to consume two or four stacks instead of all six. The damage will be lowered, but it may be useful in situations where the enemy has low HP.

Yanagi will then launch two EX Special Attacks that instantly trigger Disorder and grant Miyabi four points of Fallen Frost stacks. Yanagi needs to regenerate her EX Special Attack as soon as possible in this team, so replacing her Anomaly Mastery on Drive Disc 6 with Energy Regen helps the rotation become even smoother.

You can use any other Anomaly unit that can help trigger Disorder, but they wonâ€™t be as effective as Yanagi in Zenless Zone Zero .

Before creating chaos with Miyabi and Yanagi, make sure to first activate Yuzuha 's buff, which grants ATK, Anomaly Buildup Rate, Anomaly DMG, and Disorder DMG boosts.

Team Roles

  • Miyabi: Main DPS
  • Yanagi: Sub-DPS, Disorder trigger
  • Yuzuha: Buffer

2 Miyabi + Yanagi + Soukaku

This Miyabi team in ZZZ heavily relies on the rotation between Miyabi and Yanagi to abuse the Disorder mechanic. On the other hand, Soukaku is here to buff both Anomaly units on top of giving Ice DMG buff and Ice RES debuff.

Soukaku can trigger Quick Assist and give an ATK buff by holding her EX Special Attack , which will trigger the Fly the Flag ability. However, instead of immediately holding her EX Special Attack, start by tapping EX Special Attack until she's out of Energy, then hold when she can no longer use the tap move. The taps will build up her Vortex stacks. When Soukaku uses Fly the Flag while having three Vortex stacks, she will consume them and double her ATK buff . So, instead of 500 ATK, she gives 1000 ATK.

You can also swap Soukaku with Caesar , who offers the team more survivability while increasing the teamâ€™s DMG through her various buffs and debuffs, or Astra Yao , who can effortlessly grant an ATK buff and enable constant Quick Assist between Miyabi and Yanagi.

Team Roles

  • Miyabi: Main DPS
  • Yanagi: Sub-DPS, Disorder trigger
  • Soukaku: Buffer, debuffer

3 Miyabi + Vivian + Astra Yao

Vivian is a decent replacement for Miyabi team comp in ZZZ . She's a sub-DPS who's adept at dealing off-field damage, building up Ether Anomaly, and triggering Disorder with minimum field time. To complement this, add Astra Yao , who also uses minimum field time and constantly allows players to switch between Vivian and Miyabi through her Quick Assist ability.

Of course, Astra Yao is replaceable with Agents like Yanagi, Yuzuha, Caesar, and Soukaku.

Team Roles

  • Miyabi: Main DPS
  • Vivian: Sub-DPS, Disorder trigger
  • Astra Yao: Buffer

4 Miyabi + Piper + Lucy

For an F2P Miyabi team, team her up with Piper and Lucy, who can already work together. Lucy being a Support unit in Zenless Zone Zero will trigger Miyabiâ€™s Additional Ability. Moreover, both Piper and Lucy are from the same Faction, which also activates their Additional Abilities.

In this F2P Miyabi team, she depends more on her own kit as she needs it to build up her stacks. Piper will be able to trigger a quick Disorder, but her kit doesnâ€™t come close to how broken Yanagi is with Miyabi. Triggering Disorder will grant Miyabi two stacks of her charge attack, which leaves the other 4 stacks for her EX Special Attack and Ultimate. Meanwhile, Lucy operates as a Support buffer who can maximize this F2P team in Zenless Zone Zero .

There are other Anomaly and Support combinations that work with Miyabi if players have one other 5-star Anomaly character in their roster. For example, Jane + Soukaku, Burnice/Vivian/Yuzuha + Lucy, standard banner combo Rina + Grace, and so on.

Team Roles

  • Miyabi: Main DPS
  • Piper: Sub-DPS, Disorder trigger
  • Lucy: Buffer
